summary: This is a motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team to exclude any evidence the government intends to offer under Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b), arguing the government failed to comply with the rule's amended notice requirements. The motion criticizes the government's vague disclosure letter and requests either exclusion of the evidence or additional time for the defense to investigate and respond.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, filing a motion to exclude evidence the government seeks to admit under Rule 404(b).

Sternheim is listed as defense counsel for Maxwell.

events.title: Amendment to Federal Rule of Evidence 404(b)
events.description: Rule 404(b) was amended to impose additional notice requirements on prosecutors in criminal cases, requiring specific identification of evidence, articulation of non-propensity purpose, and reasoning.

events.title: Government's Rule 404(b) Disclosure Deadline
events.description: Court-ordered deadline for the government to provide disclosure of any Rule 404(b) evidence and notice to the defense.

events.title: Government Serves 'Maxwell Rule 404(b) Letter'
events.description: The government served a letter referencing two sets of evidence: emails between Maxwell and third-party men about setting up dates, and a witness who worked for Epstein from 2005-06.

events.title: Filing of Motion to Exclude 404(b) Evidence
events.description: Maxwell's defense team files this motion to exclude evidence due to the government's alleged failure to comply with Rule 404(b) notice requirements.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The defense argues the government failed to comply with amended Rule 404(b) notice requirements by not specifically identifying evidence, articulating a non-propensity purpose, and providing reasoning.
The government's disclosure letter referenced emails between Maxwell and 'influential' men about setting up dates and a witness who worked for Epstein from 2005-2006.

The defense claims the government also provided numerous trial exhibits dated after the charged conspiracy (post-2004), such as flight logs from 2005-2013, which were not mentioned in the Rule 404(b) letter.
Maxwell's attorneys request the court either exclude the 404(b) evidence or grant them additional time to investigate and respond to the government's disclosures.

The motion suggests the government's described evidence (emails about adult dating, testimony about post-conspiracy events) does not appear to be 'direct evidence' of the charged conspiracy to traffic minors.
